answers.author: Derek Johnson
answers.text:
Pamela,
Any policies encouraging auto industry growth at the local level should take into account measures passed or being considered at the state and federal level. For example, U.S. Congressman David Dreier (R-CA) introduced legislation in 2009 providing tax credits on purchases of new and old cars up to $50,000.
http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c111:H.R.+100
The Commonsense Auto Recovery Act (CAR) is currently sitting in the House Ways and Means Committee, which means these ideas can still be implemented at the individual state and local level. 
In terms of general ideas, this international example from Australia demonstrates a market-based approach to local government stimulation of auto industries. 
http://bit.ly/bXojCF
Though it's not a domestic example, the document outlines general advice (such as transparency, uniform emission standards and certifications) that crosses oceans in its applicability. Check out the microeconomics section for the relevant data.
Does anyone have examples of specific policies enacted in their towns, cities or counties that are geared towards supporting local auto industry growth?
Derek Johnson

author: Pamela Muse
text:
A Centeral California City is interested in learning what other local governments are doing with regard to their economic development strategies to support their auto dealers?   
For example, Tracy, CA has an "economic stimulus program" to increase auto sales--the City provided $500 in incentive funds for each car purchased that could be spent within the City in other businesses.      
Please forward your creative ideas/solutions/programs, etc.  
Thank you,  
Pamela Muse   
Western Regional Director  
Alliance for Innovation   
888-468-6450  
pmuse@transformgov.org
title: Economic Development Strategies to Support Auto Dealers
